data.title: 21 actors whose Southern accents are real
data.meta_description: Here are 21 actors whose Southern accents are real.
data.text:
Kelly Kazek | kkazek@al.com

21 actors whose Southern actors are real

(Lucas black with Billy Bob Thornton in 'Sling Blade.')

21 actors whose Southern accents are real

If you thought Reese Witherspoon's Tennessee accent was spot-on as June Carter Cash in "Walk the Line," it's because she grew up in Nashville. Actors often work hard to lose Southern accents -- until a part calls for one. Here are 21 actors whose Southern accents are real. This is not meant to be a list of all Southern actors. To suggest your favorite, email kkazek@al.com.

(Lucas Black in NCIS: New Orleans/CBS.com)

Lucas Black

Yes, that thick drawl you heard in 1996's "Sling Blade" and more recently in TV's "NCIS: New Orleans" is real. Lucas Black, born Nov. 29, 1982, in Speake, Ala., is a rare actor who has refused to lose his accent for roles. Listen to Black's accent here.

(Reese Witherspoon as June Carter Cash in "Walk the Line"/20th Century Fox)

Reese Witherspoon

You heard Witherspoon's drawl in "Walk the Line" and "Sweet Home Alabama." She comes by it honestly. She was born March 22, 1976, in New Orleans and was raised in Nashville, Tenn. Click here to hear Reese sing as June Carter Cash.

(Diane Ladd in "Wild at Heart"/ DianeLadd.com)

Diane Ladd

Diane Ladd was born Nov. 29, 1935, in Meridian, Miss. She has played numerous Southerners onscreen, including Marietta Fortune in 1990’s “Wild at Heart,” a Southern road film starring Ladd’s daughter with Bruce Dern, Laura Dern. She received an Oscar nomination for Best Supporting Actress for the Role. She would also earn nominations for “Alice Doesn’t Live Here Anymore” and “Rambling Rose.”

(Dakota Fanning, right, with Queen Latifah in "The Secret Life of Bees"/Fox Searchlight/AL.com/File Photo)

Dakota Fanning

Dakota Fanning, an accomplished child actress who has successfully transitioned to adult roles, was born Feb. 23, 1994, in Conyers, Ga. She put her accent to good use in the Southern feature “The Secret Life of Bees,” in which she starred with Queen Latifah.

(Morgan Freeman in "Driving Miss Daisy")

Morgan Freeman

Although Morgan Freeman’s distinctive deep voice is one of the most recognized in the world, he can call on his Tennessee roots when needed to give it that Southern touch. Freeman was born June 1, 1937, in Memphis. One of his best-known Southern roles was as Hoke Colburn in 1989’s “Driving Miss Daisy,” which won the Oscar for Best Film that year.

(Megan Fox and Josh Brolin in a scene from "Jonah Hex"/ AP Photo/Warner Bros.)

Megan Fox

Megan Fox was born May 16, 1986, in Oak Ridge, Tenn. She is best known for her roles in the “Transformer” films. She put her accent to good use as Leila in 2010’s “Jonah Hex.”

(Octavia Spencer in The Help/Dale Robinette/(c)Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures/Courtesy Everett Collection)

Octavia Spencer

Octavia Spencer was born May 25, 1970, in Montgomery, Ala. She played dozens of character roles before landing the part of her career to date: Minny Jackson in “The Help.” Spencer won a Best Supporting Actress Oscar and numerous other awards for her portrayal of the feisty maid in 1960s Mississippi.

(Delta Burke as Suzanne Sugarbaker on "Designing Women")

Delta Burke

One of Delta Burke's most famous roles was as the quintessential Southern beauty queen Suzanne Sugarbaker on TV's "Designing Women." Burke was born July 20, 1956, in Orlando, Fla. She is married to fellow Southerner Gerald McRaney. Click here to listen to one of her most famous quotes from "Designing Women."

(Gerald McRaney in "Simon &Simon"/AL.com/File Photo)

Gerald McRaney

Gerald McRaney was born Aug. 19, 1947, in Collins, Miss. He is best known for roles on TV shows such as “Simon & Simon,” “Major Dad” and “Deadwood.” He also had a recurring role as a Southern writer and Suzanne Sugarbaker’s ex-husband on “Designing Women.” He would marry Delta Burke, who portrayed Suzanne Sugarbaker, in 1989.

(Sandra Bullock, right, with Ellen Bustyn in "Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood"/ Michael Tackett/Warner Brothers and Gaylord Films/The New York Times)

Sandra Bullock

Sandra Bullock has played many Southern roles, including Ellen Roark in “A Time to Kill,” Birdie Pruitt in “Hope Floats” and Siddalee Walker in “Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood.” Perhaps her most iconic role was as famed Alabama author Nelle Harper Lee in “Infamous.” She was born July 26, 1964 in Arlington, Va., to Alabama native John W. Bullock.

(Dennis Quaid as Sam Houston in "The Alamo"/ Touchstone Pictures Imagine Entertainment)

Dennis Quaid

Dennis Quaid, born April 9, 1954, in Houston, Texas, has played several Southern roles, including the legendary Sam Houston in 2004's "The Alamo." Click to hear Quaid's drawl in the trailer for "The Alamo."

(Mary-Louise Parker in "Fried Green Tomatoes"/Al.com File Photo)

Mary-Louise Parker

Mary-Louise Parker was born Aug. 2, 1964, in Fort Jackson, S.C. Although she is known more recently for portraying a drug-dealing single mom on TV's "Weeds," her most quintessential Southern role was as Ruth Jamison in 1991's "Fried Green Tomatoes," based on the book by Alabama-born author and actress Fannie Flagg. Click to hear Parker in "Fried Green Tomatoes."

(Renee Zellweger in "Cold Mountain"/ Phil Bray/Miramax Films)

Renee Zellweger

Renee Zellweger was born April 25, 1969, in Katy, Texas. She has won praise for numerous film roles, including 1996's "Jerry Maguire," 2001's "Bridget Jones' Diary," and 2002's "Chicago" but her most memorable role was as a tough-talking, Civil War-era Southern woman in 2003's "Cold Mountain." She won an Oscar for Best Supporting Actress for the role of Ruby Thewes. Click here to listen to Zellweger as Ruby.

(Jim Nabors as Gomer Pyle on "The Andy Griffith Show"/ AL.com/File Photo)

Jim Nabors

Jim Nabors, born June 12, 1930, in Sylacauga, Ala., is best known for playing the quintessential good ol' boy Gomer Pyle on "The Andy Griffith Show." That role led to his own series, "Gomer Pyle, U.S.M.C." Although he is now better known for his baritone singing voice, Nabors' distinctive drawl made Gomer Pyle his most memorable persona. Listen to it here in a clip from "The Andy Griffith Show."

(Julia Roberts in "Steel Magnolias"/AL.com/File Photo)

Julia Roberts

Julia Roberts was born Oct. 28, 1967, in Smyrna, Ga. One of her best-known early roles put her Southern accent to good use portraying Shelby Eatenton Latcherie in "Steel Magnolias." She was nominated for a Best Supporting Actress Oscar for the role. She was also nominated for an Oscar for her roles in "Pretty Woman and "August: Osage County." She won a Best Actress Oscar for the title role in "Erin Brockovich." Listen to Roberts as Shelby Eatenton in a scene from "Steel Magnolias."

(Andie McDowell/AP Photo/Danny Moloshok)

Andie McDowell

Andie McDowell was born April 21, 1958, in Gaffney, S.C. Although her Southern accent is often evident in her film roles, it was particularly heavy in 2015’s “Magic Mike XXL,” in which she portrayed a wealthy Southerner.

(Harry Connick Jr. in "Hope Floats")

Harry Connick Jr.

Harry Connick Jr, born Sept. 11, 1967, in New Orleans, La., is best known as a jazz singer but he puts his distinctive Southern accent to good use in film roles, as well. It can be heard as the Mississippi narrator in “My Dog Skip,” and when Connick played the romantic lead in 1998’s “Hope Floats” opposite Sandra Bullock.

(Actress Lacey Chabert on the red carpet at the Mobile, Ala., premiere of "Hometown Legend"/Mobile Register, John David Mercer

Lacey Chabert

Lacey Chabert, who began her career on the TV show “Party of Five” and had a memorable role in 2004’s “Mean Girls,” Lacey Chabert was born Sept. 30, 1982, in Purvis, Miss. She has portrayed Southerners, most notably as Rachel Sawyer in 2002’s“Hometown Legend,” which was filmed in Foley and Mobile, Ala.

(Kim Dickens/Photo by Evan Agostini/Invision/AP Photo)

Kim Dickens

Kim Dickens was born June 18, 1965, in Huntsville, Ala. She is currently known for her role in AMC’s “Fear the Walking Dead” and has previously had roles in “Deadwood,” “12 Miles of Bad Road,” “Lost” and “Friday Night Lights.” She has also starred in numerous films, such as 2009’s “The Blind Side” and 2011’s “Footloose.” She most recently portrayed Det. Rhonda Boney in “Gone Girl.”

(Michael C. Hall in the TV series "Dexter"/Christian Weber/AL.com/File Photo)

Michael C. Hall

Michael C. Hall, born Feb. 1, 1971, in Raleigh, N.C., initially drew praise for his role in the HBO series “Six Feet Under,” and has since won Golden Globe and Screen Actors Guild awards for the title role in the Showtime series “Dexter.” He played a blood-spatter expert for the Miami Police Department who moonlighted as a serial killer.
